What I would say is that I think it's a wrong conclusion to say that another's growth has been at our expense, because clearly when you look at the numbers and the market share numbers, the growth that someone else has got has been at others' expense and not necessarily us, because in food we actually outgrew them in market share growth. In liquor, we outgrew them in market share growth.
So I understand where your logic and comments come from, but it's not one that I subscribe to and I guess we'll have to agree to disagree on that.

If we look at the fourth quarter, Mike, I know that your metric was that you want to be growing faster than your competitor, et cetera. The only reason that you're growing market share faster is because you're investing more money. If you look at the sales per square meter, my calculations in fourth quarter your sales per square meter actually went down for Australian Supermarkets and when you're saying that you're dropping price or you're pulling price for BIG W and for food and liquor, it doesn't seem to be gaining traction because your sales are just slowing to a trickle?

What's less so gone to a trickle is our volume, which is the reflection of our investment in price because our volumes actually were very strong and all the market data that I look at, doesn't matter whether it's liquor or whether it's food, we actually outgrew in percentage terms market share growth. In fresh, we maintained and grew our share. What I saw with others what they actually got back was their loss of fresh to specialists that were very obvious in the previous years. So once again, it's not at our expense. The numbers are really clear, David.

I'm concerned that with the 1.7% comp that was in the second half, and you're basically saying that that's sustained and BIG W again like I still can't quite understand how the gross margin could go up 400 basis points in the second half when your sales dropped about 7%. I still don't quite understand how that works when you're saying you're pushing the price lever on that?

Well, it's the mathematics that you actually earn a lot more than 400 basis points and you're able to put some of those back in. And also you earn in CODB improvements, both of those go back into a different price position in the marketplace, it's no different than what we've done every year for a long, long time.
Cost base.
The formula hasn't changed.
Are you concerned about the EBIT for food and liquor being too high, the EBIT margin, because it's getting up to 7.2%. That's miles above world's best standards and how far can you push that up?

We'll continue to register that each time we come in and talk in six-month time, David, and 12 months times and 18 months time, and 24 months time. We have always said that we're going to generate, as we've been able to do for a decade now, improvements in cost of doing business, improvement in cost of goods sold and we will determine at the appropriate time how much the customer gets and how much the shareholder gets, and we'll continue to do that.

If I move onto the cash flow, when I look at your cash flow statement from operations it was 2.76 billion, CapEx was 1.8. So your free cash flow is 9.40. You did purchase some businesses for 200 and your dividends paid was 1.16. So when you look at your free cash, it's significantly below what your dividend payment is and yet you're doing an off-market buyback. I can't quite fully understand why you'd want to be doing an off-market buyback when your operating cash flow at the moment after your CapEx is not enough to support your dividend?

David, capital management and managing our balance sheet to maintaining our credit ratings is what we do. The fact that in one year the cash generated from the business doesn't cover the dividends, the key issue is do we have capacity in our balance sheet to do capital management, pay dividends, invest in our business and buy growth opportunities? And the answer is absolutely. So I think you've got quite a narrow view of capital management.

And the final question I've got is you mentioned Mike that Consumer Electronics you basically are confident in the strategy that you're adopting much along the lines that you're confident in the turnaround in New Zealand that I would have thought it's a little early to be popping Champagne corks in New Zealand given that you generated 232 million of EBIT from capital employed of nearly 3 billion, that's about a 7.5% return on funds employed, so you still – and you're about five or six years in on that?

Well, just – you might recall we've had this conversation several times, David. You're only looking at one part of the return. We got a significant return through that transaction directly attributable to that transaction in our Australian Supermarkets by renegotiating our business terms with our major trading partners and they're still in place. It's still generating additional income.

We got 20 stores and a number of development sites as a result of that. We continue to get benefit from those. We also got a taxation advantage through having a business in New Zealand. When you put all those together, actually we get a far better return than the one that you've calculated.

Well, on the numbers that Tom said that he said that with the CapEx you got a 36% uplift on the Australian EBIT in the last three years. If you pull that out, the underlying business is growing at about 5.5, 6% and with inflation at 3.5, 4%. And then if you throw in all the benefits that you have supposed to have got from New Zealand, the underlying Australian business without that CapEx and without New Zealand is probably pretty flat?
When we come visit you, you put the calculation in front of us and we'll indicate where you may have miscalculated.

And your statement about popping Champagne corks, David, that's your statement, Michael was really clear in his comment that we have a long way to go. We have got good competitors, so that's not a correct statement of our view.
Okay.
The next question comes from Rob Blythe from Macquarie.

Yes. Hi, guys. How are you? Another question on Dick Smith, as you roll out the new format across the network over the next two years, it's also going to have a negative impact on your gross margin at the mix, so what are you expecting in terms of cost of doing business to negate this?

Clearly, there are a number of things. As the new stores come out, we get a bit of sales numbers so that it helps us fractionalize fixed cost, but we worked very hard on reducing fixed cost on the last 12 months. We just completed rolling the New Zealand office into the Australian office.

We have recalibrated our supply chain costs in both businesses and we have the opportunity now, now that we've established better volumes to go back and re-negotiate our cost of goods sold. So they will be both elements that will improve our return in those businesses.
Okay. And you also mentioned that Consumer Electronics is doing well in July and August. Can you comment on maybe what products or categories is driving the growth over that, time?

It continues to be the products that have been the backbone. So TVs, but iPads certainly has been a tremendous sales success. But also we're seeing a bit of rejuvenation in photography. So cameras and also in-car navigation's having a bit of a second life. But the area that really has been fantastic growth has been phones, particularly smartphones.
Okay. Thanks.

Okay. We need to call a halt here now because I think we've got some TV cameras that have been waiting patiently for us. So, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your time today. And we appreciate your interest in our company. Thank you.
